xldoc.title: History of Philosophical Logic - Part I
xldoc.description: A history of logic and of the concept of logical truth
xldoc.keywords: rbjones philosophy analytic semantics meaning necessity logic metaphysics

section.title: Overview
section.abstract: First part of a history of Philosophical Logic reaching Russell's Logical Atomism and Wittgenstein's Tractatus via Aristotle, Leibniz, Hume, Kant and Frege.

section.title: Introduction
section.abstract: This presents an informal view of a project consisting of a selective history of philosophical logic and related areas making use of a method for formal logical analysis and providing the historical background underpinning and leading to that method.

subsec.title: Scope and Emphasis
subsec.p: The aim of this historical sketch is to examine the history of logic and certain related areas with particular concern for the evolution of the concept of logical truth, and related concepts. These include the notion of empirical fact, the concepts if logical necessity, contingency, analyticity, the synthetic. The demarcation of logical truth involves semantics, and metaphysics, and our story therefore embraces these closely related areas of logic and philosophy.

sbcol.subsec: The full material, formal and informal, will be prepared chapter by chapter in PDF documents which will be available from RBJones.com as they are prepared. In addition informal accounts will be available here in HTML, often as sketches before the detailed preparation. Links on the list of chapters will reach the current PDF of any chapters which I have made a start on. Information presented here in HTML will include my ideas about what I should be doing with a chapter before I actually start.

The full list will not be finalised for a while, but the earlier chapters are pencilled in as:
Introduction
Plato and Aristotle
Leibniz
Hume and Kant
Frege
Russell and Wittgenstein
The book will probably come in two volumes, the first containing the main body of the analysis, the second containing a set of listings of the formal theories developed in the analysis.
